page.title: 18Wildlife in Ceres District
page.content: Rabbits are the most common mammals. Hares are most often seen when the fields are bare. Foxes are often seen in car headlights at night but, so far, prefer not to visit the villages. Their numbers are kept partly under control by Fife Foxhounds who hunt over the area. Groups of roe deer are seen near woodland where there is enough cover. As well as the more common birds like sparrows, blackbirds, starlings, rooks and thrushes, the area is visited more often nowadays by herons because of the fish available in Ceres Burn and a pair of sedge warblers have been nesting in an area of rough ground in the area. There are many types of finches. Swallows, martins and swifts are regular visitors. Kestrels are seen fairly often but the number of barn owls has decreased.
